profiles.description: Practicing cardiologist Dr. Shiv Rao founded Abridge in 2018 to free clinicians from the time-sucking paperwork that's required after they see patients: jotting down detailed notes for their medical records. Instead, Abridge records their conversations with patients and uses AI to both summarize them and fill out electronic health forms. Thousands of clinicians at health systems like John Hopkins Medicine and Mayo Clinic are already using it. In June, the startup announced a $300 million series E funding round supported by Andreessen Horowitz and Khosla Ventures, bumping its valuation to $5.3 billion.

Anthropic has climbed to No. 2 on this year's Cloud 100 list. Anthropic has continued to be the OpenAI challenger with the most staying power. In February, it released a “hybrid reasoning” model called Claude 3.7 Sonnet that can automatically decide how to approach a question—either taking time to process it by breaking it down to smaller chunks or answering it quickly in real time. The company has also pushed into software development, releasing Claude Code, an AI system that can search and read code, edit files and run commands among a slew of other software engineering functions. CEO Dario Amodei has said that in about a year, all code might be written by AI. Most recently, Anthropic paired up with Databricks, another Cloud 100 lister, to sell AI agents—software that can autonomously carry out specific tasks—to thousands of enterprise customers. In March, Anthropic nabbed $3.5 billion in a Series E funding round led by Lightspeed Venture Partners with a post-money valuation of $61.5 billion. The company released a new Claude Opus model in August, and in July, the US Department of Defense awarded Anthropic a contract of up to $200 million to work on AI capabilities that further US national security. In September, the company secured another $13 billion in a Series F funding round led by ICONIQ at a $183 billion post-money valuation.

AI coding tool Cursor is among the hottest products in a very hot AI market. It’s the only product of parent company Anysphere, which is growing superfast; it’s said to have signed $100 million in contracts in about a year — a figure that has since reportedly doubled. Founded in 2022 by 24-year-old Michael Truell and three MIT classmates, Cursor helps engineers from companies including Instacart and Samsung edit code with nontechnical prompts in everyday language that can be as simple as “make me an 8-bit side-scroller video game” or “build me a weather app.” They’re already taking on giants like Github Copilot in the global market for automated coding, which is expected to reach $30 billion by 2032. “The ambition of the company is to completely change how people build software,” Truell says.

As the AI wave matures, “inference,” the act of running an AI model and allowing it to “think” and reason like a human, has become more important than just shoveling data into the model to “train” it. That's Baseten's sweet spot. The company has developed a cloud that uses software tricks to make inference faster; CEO and cofounder Tuhin Srivastava claims some clients switching from competitors see inference costs fall up to 65%, with better performance to boot. Baseten scored a $75 million boost of funding in February, valuing it at $850 million, and Srivastava sees infinite promise: “You train once, you infer forever.”

Online influencers can help companies boost sales — but hiring a human to promote your product involves contracts, usage rights and, of course, payments. Captions, a generative video editing and creating company led by CEO and cofounder Gaurav Misra, allows brands to create realistic human-looking “AI brand avatars” that can generate quick ads and social media posts, complete with AI-generated voiceovers based on a provided script. The concept has attracted heavyweight investors including Kleiner Perkins, Sequoia Capital, and Andreessen Horowitz, which participated in a $60 million Series C funding round last fall that netted the company a $500 million valuation.

Kareem Amin has a unique background for a tech founder: He once worked in journalism. Before starting Clay, a $3.1 billion unicorn that makes AI-powered spreadsheets for sales teams, he was the vice president of product for the Wall Street Journal, where he developed software that let reporters publish data-driven articles on mobile phones. “I was really interested in building tools for programming for non-programmers,” Amin says. “In that case, it was journalists.” Now the target is businesses both large and small. Corporate clients OpenAI and Anthropic use Clay to organize sales leads and suss out new ones. A protein-shake vendor, say, could use its software to pull location, phone numbers and user ratings on gyms across the country.

Anyone who has ever selected the number of bicycles in an image to “prove your humanity” knows that deciphering a photo is an especially tricky task for machines. Enter Coactive AI, which builds a set of pre-trained AI models that can parse through large amounts of raw visual data without relying on a human to identify more than a couple of examples. One real world application is content moderation: Coactive can sort prohibited and accepted images and video automatically. Companies have also used it to make sense of mountains of photo assets. Led by Cody Coleman, a computer science alum from both Stanford and MIT, Coactive AI has raised $44 million in funding, reaching a valuation of $200 million after its Series B in May 2024. It's also been selected as one of Forbes' next billion-dollar startups.

Cohere focuses on creating language models for AI research as well as enterprise applications. In fact, cofounder and CEO Aidan Gomez was one of the coauthors of a key research paper that sparked the development of generative AI. He and cofounders Nick Frosst and Ivan Zhang have deep ties to Google Brain, where Gomez and Frosst worked under famed technologist Geoffrey Hinton in Toronto while Zhang was known to come by to hang out after work. Cohere has since become an industry darling, reaching a $5.5 billion valuation from backers including Salesforce and Nvidia. But not everyone is impressed. In February, Forbes and a group of publishers including The Atlantic and Vox sued Cohere for alleged copyright and trademark violation. Cohere has denied the allegations, calling the suit “misguided and frivolous.”

AI companies that were once constrained by the supply of advanced Nvidia chips face a new roadblock: power. Systems like ChatGPT consume tons of electricity, enough for tens of thousands of homes. Enter Crusoe Energy. The $2.8 billion-valued company has a knack for finding untapped energy sources in remote places like North Dakota and Iceland and building datacenters to power compute-heavy tasks, starting with cryptocurrency mining and now running and training AI models. The startup is building one of the largest datacenters in the world in Abilene, Texas as the lead developer of the first site of Project Stargate— the $500 billion AI infrastructure joint initiative backed by OpenAI, SoftBank, Oracle and MGX. CEO Chase Lochmiller, who summited Mount Everest before starting Crusoe in 2018, says “we're building the factory of factories.”

Why IPO when you can continue raising money? That appears to be Databricks' motto. In December 2024, the data infrastructure company raised a $10 billion Series J round for a whopping $62 billion valuation–and it's currently raising a series K that may value it over $100 billion. Under the leadership of CEO Ali Ghodsi, one of seven academics from the University of California, Berkeley who cofounded the company in 2013, the startup—which has more than 15,000 customers—now plans to achieve $3.7 billion in annualized revenue by July. The company's data warehousing product, Databricks SQL, is forecast to hit $1 billion in revenue run rate by the end of the fiscal month of January 2026, and in the past year, the company—which supports AI and machine learning app development—has announced seven new offices around the globe, including offices in Mexico, Saudi Arabia and London. Databricks has also announced strategic partnerships with defense software company Palantir and generative AI company Anthropic, maker of ChatGPT competitor Claude.

“We think AI agents can be 10x employees,” says Jesse Zhang, cofounder and CEO of Decagon. That's why Zhang, 27, named his company, which builds customer service bots, after the 10-sided geometric shape. The startup's pitch to corporate clients, which include public companies like Duolingo and Hertz alongside buzzy startups such as Notion and Rippling, is that its AI can help consumers return products, cancel subscriptions or order replacement credit cards. Zhang says his secret sauce is that Decagon's bots can appear to empathize with frustrated users—which is more than can be said of the average call center employee. “We give a very, very personalized experience.”

One of Google Translate's top rivals, DeepL was founded in 2017 by Polish entrepreneur Jaroslaw Kutylowski. Its AI-powered software enables users to translate text and files into 30 different languages, including Estonian, Japanese and Portuguese, or to make writing in another language sound more natural. DeepL's free basic service has been used by millions of people, and it claims to have more than 200,000 business users, including Zendesk, Coursera and Klarna. In May 2024, the Cologne, Germany-based company cracked a $2 billion valuation. It achieved HIPAA compliance earlier this year, which enables its translation services to be integrated into healthcare tools. In March, the company launched Clarify, an interactive feature to help users understand translation decisions.

Changing the sound of your voice, cloning your voice, or even making yourself sound like you're speaking in a different language is all possible with ElevenLabs' software. The generative AI audio company has 45 pre-made voices for dubbing podcasts, narrating audiobooks and creating voiceovers. CEO Mati Staniszewski started the company with childhood friend Piotr Dabkowski in 2022 after being frustrated by poorly dubbed films. The Polish duo landed on the Forbes 30 Under 30 Europe list last year and have raised $281 million for their company at a valuation of $3.3 billion. But it has also taken heat from voice actors, who have sued the company for allegedly cloning their voices without permission (ElevenLabs has asked for the claims to be dismissed due to a lack of evidence). The software was also used to create a fake robocall that imitated Biden's voice, urging voters in New Hampshire not to vote. In response, ElevenLabs reportedly suspended the account behind the deepfake for violating its policies. In August, the company launched Eleven Music, which uses text prompts to generate songs and is available for commercial use.

Figure AI wants robots to take our jobs. Or at least the jobs that have labor shortages, like those in warehouses and retail. The company's bipedal humanoid robots, which currently stand at 5 feet 6 inches and weigh 154 pounds, are perfectly suited to take over the jobs that humans don't want, according to CEO Brett Adcock, who founded the company in 2022. In a world where Tesla and other companies are starting to build their own androids, Figure AI's pitch has been compelling enough to land customers like BMW, which plans to use the robots in their factories, and investors including Jeff Bezos, OpenAI's startup fund, Microsoft and Nvidia. In February 2024, the company raised $754 million at a valuation of $2.6 billion.

Fireworks AI CEO Lin Qiao is one of the pioneers of what's called “compound AI” systems—techniques that use multiple AI models that each tackle specific tasks, rather than one larger model that tries to do it all. Her company, Fireworks AI, a Forbes Next Billion-Dollar Startup listmaker, provides the background infrastructure for AI developers to run more than 100 generative AI models and decide which one is the best for a given application. It boasts customers like Samsung, Doordash and Verizon, and has caught the eye of investors like Sequoia Capital and Nvidia. Last July, it raised a $52 million funding round at a valuation of $552 million.

Think of Glean like a ChatGPT for your workplace—one that can tell you everything from how many vacation days you have left, to that obscure employee discount you'd forgotten. The AI-powered search tool—used by over 1 million employees on teams at companies like Booking.com, Deutsche Telekom and Duolingo—is trained on a company's entire database, allowing employees to get quick access to their pressing questions by pinging customizable AI agents in Slack, Teams and Zendesk. In February, the unicorn company claimed it had $100 million in annualized revenue, and in June, the company secured $150 million in a Series F funding round led by Wellington Management—upping its valuation to $7.2 billion. Glean Agents, which the company introduced in May, allows employees to create and scale agents without coding.

Lawyers' desks are notoriously covered in paperwork, but Harvey can make all that clutter disappear. The AI company is built to securely store thousands of sensitive documents – including court records – and quickly allow lawyers to get answers to complex legal queries. Winston Weinberg and Gabriel Pereyra cofounded the startup in 2022, and in the past year it has grown from 40 customers to 235, including the majority of top 10 U.S. law firms. Recently, the startup raised a $300 million series E round, boosting its valuation to $5 billion, and announced plans to expand coverage to India, Australia and Germany.

profiles.industry: General purpose AI for finance and legal
profiles.description: Hebbia is on a mission to build a general purpose AI software that's more useful for business. The company's interface, called Matrix, enables lawyers, financial advisors and others to upload millions of pages of public and private documents, then query all that information for analysis and insights. Founder George Sivulka, a Forbes 30 Under 30 alumnus, dropped out of a fully-funded Stanford Ph.D. program at 23 to start the company. After raising a $130 million Series B last year led by Andreessen Horowitz, the company has a current valuation of $700 million.

What started as an AI chatbot for teens in 2016 has become an open-source platform worth $4.5 billion. Founded by Clement Delangue, Julien Chaumond and Thomas Wolf, Hugging Face has some 10 million users who use it to share code and collaborate on models, datasets and apps. The platform hosts a library of models and datasets from 215,000 firms including Meta and Microsoft as well as government organizations like France's Ministry of Culture, Poland's Ministry of Digital Affairs and UNESCO. The company has raised a total of $395.2 million in funding from tech heavyweights like Amazon, Google and Nvidia. It acquired Pollen Robotics in April and launched its first-ever robotics product, Reachy Mini, which gathered over $1 million in sales in less than a week.

Twin brothers Michael and Stephen Balaban founded Lambda as an AI photo editing app in 2012, but saw a bigger opportunity when their app ran up tens of thousands of dollars in compute bills from cloud provider Amazon Web Services. In 2017, they began building their own cluster of graphic processing units (GPUs) to sell to other companies. Since then, demand for the San Jose, California-based company's hardware and cloud computing services has skyrocketed with the AI boom. The unicorn— valued at $2.5 billion—has become a top GPU cloud for developers at organizations like Intel, Microsoft and the Department of Defense, allowing them to build, test and deploy AI products at scale. Lambda boasts 15,000 paying customers and has raised over $863 million in investment to date, most recently a $480 million Series D co-led by Andra Capital and SGW in February 2025.

LangChain wants to make it easy to build apps powered by large language models like OpenAI's GPT-4. Harrison Chase and Ankush Gola founded the San Fransisco-based startup in 2023 with a goal of producing apps more quickly–with as little as two dozen lines of code. Developers use LangChain to build generative AI-based applications, from legal document review to processing refunds to customers, going from idea to code in an afternoon. The startup has also launched LangSmith, which developers on over 40,000 teams use to evaluate, monitor and debug underlying LLMs. Teams at Uber, LinkedIn and GitLab use its tool, LangGraph, to build “agents,” systems that autonomously carry out specific actions. It has raised a total of $35 million from marquee investors like Benchmark and Sequoia Capital. Valued at $200 million, LangChain counts firms like TikTok parent Bytedance, Google, The Home Depot, Rakuten and Klarna among its customers.

Luminance sits at the intersection of AI and the legal world. Founded in 2015 by mathematicians Adam Guthrie and Graham Sills, the startup's AI helps businesses with contract generation, negotiation and contract analysis. The Cambridge-based company has raised a total of $165 million in funding, and its most recent Series C round brought in $75 million in February. Luminance—valued at $400 million, according to PitchBook—boasts over 700 customers in over 70 countries, including AMD, National Grid, Rolls-Royce and Lamborghini. In December, Luminance launched Lumi Go, a product that sends draft agreements to contract counterparties and can automatically negotiate on the sender's behalf.

If this $2 billion (valuation) startup has its way, your next job interview might be conducted by a robot. Mercor uses AI to automate the employment application process, identifying standout candidates from reams of cover letters and résumés and screening them via video calls with avatars. The idea is to make hiring less subjective, instead of the “very vibes-based assessment” of traditional interviews, says CEO Brendan Foody. “Our models are able to figure out the features on résumés that are actually predictive.” Foody and his cofounders, all age 21, dropped out of college to start Mercor. They're all Thiel Fellows, recipients of the $100,000 grants billionaire Peter Thiel gives to young entrepreneurs willing to skip school.

Describe it, design it. That's how people are using Midjourney's popular AI image generation tool, which is available via Discord and web app. CEO David Holz—a former NASA researcher who previously founded Leap Motion—started the San Francisco-based business in 2021. It has since been used to create everything from floral typography and watercolor-style art to realistic-looking images of Pope Francis or U.S. President Donald Trump, tapping into video generation with the release of its V1 Video Model in June. Midjourney—which brought in $300 million in total revenue in the 2024 fiscal year, according to PitchBook—has so far shunned any outside funding, but it did announce a technology licensing partnership with Meta in August. Midjourney was also hit with a lawsuit this June, with Disney and Universal suing for copyright infringement. In August, Midjourney pushed back and argued fair use for AI model training, writing that “Copyright law does not confer absolute control over the use of copyrighted works.”

Widely touted as the European rival to OpenAI, Mistral develops mostly free-of-charge open-source AI models. The two-year-old startup is valued at $6.51 billion per PitchBook, with $1.1 billion in venture capital from the likes of a16z, General Catalyst, Microsoft and Nvidia. In February, Mistral launched a new version of its AI assistant Le Chat, which it claims cranks out responses up to around 1,000 words per second, potentially making it 10 times faster than OpenAI's GPT-4o, Anthropic's Claude Sonnet 3.5 and DeepSeek R1.

Productivity doesn’t have to be all work and no play–at least, not according to Ivan Zhao, Simon Last and Akshay Kothari, cofounders of Notion. The company created collaborative workplace software where people can brainstorm, organize and gamify their goals and work habits. Major companies like OpenAI, Figma and Toyota use the software, but it has also found popularity among Gen Z after videos of people using Notion to make weekly schedules went viral on TikTok in 2021. The influx of users from the popular app was so great that it crashed the startup’s servers. Valued at $10 billion, Notion has raised a total of $330 million from the likes of Coatue, Sequoia Capital and Index Ventures and it surpassed 100 million users last year. Aside from the free plan, Notion charges upwards of $10 per month for users to access AI features that include writing and summarizing text.

OpenAI is running up against the clock. The ChatGPT maker has until the end of the year to complete a complicated transition from a non-profit to a for-profit entity in order to get its hands on a majority of its late March $40 billion funding round–the largest private tech fundraise to date. The restructuring has been challenged by former cofounder-turned-rival Elon Musk, who has asked authorities to block the transition and at one point offered to buy the nonprofit that controls OpenAI. But the $300 billion-valued behemoth continues to grow: 500 million people now use conversational bot ChatGPT weekly and it has some 2 million paying enterprise users. In March, the AI juggernaut added more advanced image generation capabilities to ChatGPT, setting off a viral and controversial trend where people created thousands of images in the style of Japanese animator Studio Ghibli, whose cofounder Hayao Miyazaki famously called AI-generated art “an insult to life itself.”

In the United States alone, more than 50 million people this year will be treated by a doctor who uses OpenEvidence, a Sequoia-backed AI company that summarizes and simplifies evidence-based medical information. Founded by Daniel Nadler and Zachary Ziegler in 2022, OpenEvidence is valued at $1 billion and has raised over $100 million in funding. Touted as “ChatGPT for doctors,” it aggregates research literature and clinical trials to help medical professionals answer questions and make decisions. In February, OpenEvidence announced a content partnership with The New England Journal of Medicine, which will provide content to inform the platform's responses.

Perplexity wants to make search engines without AI a thing of the past. Cofounded by Aravind Srinivas, Johnny Ho, Denis Yarats and Andy Konwinski in 2022, it uses a medley of AI models to answer users’ questions on a wide range of topics, which it backs up with footnoted sources. Srinivas, the CEO and an ex-OpenAI researcher, told Forbes last year that Perplexity is “almost like Wikipedia and ChatGPT had a kid.” It has some $900 million in total funding from the likes of Softbank and Nvidia and a $9 billion valuation, per PitchBook. In March, the CEO Srinivas claimed it had reached more than $100 million in annualized revenue. The company has drawn criticism from Forbes and other media outlets for allegedly plagiarizing their reporting and redistributing it across multiple platforms. Srinivas acknowledged that its republishing product feature had “rough edges” and that Perplexity was “improving it with more feedback.” Forbes sent a cease-and-desist letter to Perplexity in June 2024, accusing it of infringing copyright, to which the company said the claims are meritless and that factual information is not protected by copyright law.

No photo studio? No problem. Without any access to professional photographers and studios during the Covid-19 pandemic, small business owners and side hustlers turned to photo editing app Photoroom, which uses AI to spruce up product shots. With more than 20 million monthly users and over 200 million app downloads, the company is positioning itself as a photo editing app for the masses. The $500 million valued company allows users to level up their designs and create product pictures and logos. Warner Bros., Lionsgate and Sony Japan have used the app for film promotion, and Netflix partnered with the startup to create cover photos for the dystopian Black Mirror series. Apart from entertainment companies, it's also been used by Amazon, Klarna, Daiso and Bulgari.

With a few clicks and a simple prompt, anyone can create videos of scuba divers exploring underwater sea life or a tiger prowling through a lush Indian forest using Pika's generative AI software. Stanford Ph.D. students Demi Guo and Chenlin Meng cofounded the startup in 2023 after growing frustrated with the quality of AI video generation tools, but they now compete in a cluttered market. Pika, which recently launched a feature that allows users to take a selfie with an AI generated version of their younger self, has been used to create 58 million videos. Since its launch, the startup has raised a total of $135 million in funding at a $470 million valuation according to PitchBook and has been backed by angel investors like former GitHub CEO Nat Friedman and Quora cofounder and CEO Adam D'Angelo.

Lights, camera, Runway. Imagine cutting your video editing time from five hours to five minutes. That's exactly what the graphics team at The Late Show with Stephen Colbert has done with Runway—a startup valued $3.3 billion. Founded by Cristóbal Valenzuela, Anastasis Germanidis and Alejandro Matamala in 2018, Runway's AI image and video tools allow users to conjure up images and videos on the fly—from location changes and lighting adjustments to recasts of a character. Visual effects artist Evan Halleck used Runway to assist with the rock scene in the Oscar-winning film Everything Everywhere All at Once. This year, the New York City-based startup raised $308M in Series D funding and announced partnerships with Lionsgate, AMC Networks and Netflix.

profiles.industry: AI models for science and research
profiles.description: Headquartered in Tokyo, Sakana AI designs models by drawing inspiration from phenomena that occur in nature such as evolution and natural selection, combining the best aspects of different AI models to create an entirely new one that can perform well on a given task. Founded by former Google and Stability AI researchers David Ha, Llion Jones and Ren Ito in 2023, the startup—valued at $1.5 billion—builds open source models that are smaller in size and more cost efficient. Sakana has been backed by Nvidia, Khosla Ventures and Lux Capital among others, and in August 2024, the company released an “AI scientist” to perform experiments, conduct research and analyze data.

SambaNova is one of a number of companies vying to build the next generation of AI chips. The competition is fierce, pitting the eight-year-old startup against both legacy players like Nvidia as well as rival startups like Groq and Cerebras. SambaNova's edge comes from its focus on combining software with hardware to develop products focused specifically on AI computations and data processing for companies like Aramco, Softbank and Hugging Face. It helps that the company's cofounders include Stanford professors CTO Kunle Olukotun and Christopher Ré, along with CEO Rodrigo Liang, a former longtime senior vice president at Oracle. Since they founded SambaNova in 2017 it has raised $1.1 billion in investment from backers like Accel, OpenAI and Khosla Ventures and is valued at $5.1 billion.

Scale AI was conceived in 2016 as a one-stop shop for supplying human labor to perform tasks that could not be done by algorithms — essentially, the antithesis of AI. Cofounders Alexandr Wang and Lucy Guo had realized humans were vital in labeling the data needed to train the AI used in self-driving cars. Scale capitalized on that boom, setting itself up as a crucial data supplier for generative AI. Nearly a decade later, it works with customers like Meta, Microsoft and OpenAI on labeling training data and building infrastructure for their models. It was last valued at $13.8 billion in May after closing a $1 billion series F funding round backed by Accel, Amazon, Meta and others, cementing Wang's status as one of the world's youngest billionaires at age 28. In March, Scale AI announced a contract with the Department of Defense called Thunderforge to help it use AI for military planning and operations.

Sierra is the latest act for its CEO Bret Taylor, the OpenAI board member who was formerly Facebook CTO, Salesforce co-CEO and Twitter chairman. He started the company in 2023 with longtime Google veteran Clay Bavor with the belief that ChatGPT-style conversational AI agents would transform the way businesses interact with their customers. Those include text chats as well as voice agents, who can talk people through flight changes, shopping returns or banking questions. Traction from customers including Sonos and The North Face has helped Taylor and Bavor to raise $285 million from top VC firms Benchmark and Sequoia, reaching a $4.5 billion valuation last fall. In September, the company announced they've raised another $350 million at a valuation of $10 billion, led by Greenoaks.

Founded by former Carnegie Mellon University professors Abhinav Gupta and Deepak Pathak, Skild AI is building a one-size-fits-all AI model that can be slotted into robots of different shapes and sizes. The $1.5 billion-valued startup's secret sauce is training its AI model with 1000 times more data than its rivals, cofounders Gupta and Pathak claim. Even though the company has said little about who its customers are, it has picked up $300 million in venture funding from top investors including Lightspeed Ventures, Coatue and billionaire Jeff Bezos.

Born out of Stanford University's Artificial Intelligence Lab in 2019, Snorkel AI sells software products that allow businesses to annotate, fine-tune and label their data. The company reached a valuation of more than $1 billion after picking up $85 million in a series C in 2021, bringing its total investment to over $135 million. The company's tools have become a go-to for large companies like Google and furniture retailer Wayfair as well as several of the biggest American banks. In October 2024, the company added a slew of new capabilities for one of its flagship products, Snorkel Flow, including tools to assess the performance of an LLM and more easily extract information from PDFs.

It's nearly impossible to truly master a language without human interaction or in-person tutoring. Speak wants to change that by offering an AI tutor for users to converse with, helping them achieve fluency in English and Spanish. In December of 2024, its valuation doubled to $1 billion, after raising $78 million from OpenAI, Khosla Ventures and Y Combinator. Its founders are certainly fluent in entrepreneurship: CEO Connor Zwick previously founded video game company Coco Controller as a Harvard dropout-turned-member of the Thiel Fellowship. That was after starting online learning tool Flashcards+, which education firm Chegg acquired in 2013. Speak cofounder and CTO Andrew Hsu also dropped out of his Stanford neuroscience PhD program to be an inaugural member of the Thiel Fellowship and pursue his ed-tech startup Airy Labs.

Web development startup StackBlitz was on the verge of shuttering when it found overnight success with Bolt.new, a website-building service that integrates Anthropic’s AI models to quickly spin up web pages and apps. The company claims it reached $4 million in annualized revenue within four weeks of launching in October 2024. Bolt has since expanded to offer a tool that can turn a website into a mobile app without any coding. It raised a series B in January from VC outfits including Emergence Capital and GV (Google Ventures), which brought its total funding to $105 million and boosted it to a $700 million valuation.

Even Suno admits its technology could be a threat to the status quo of the music industry. The AI music and sound generation startup has caused a stir since its founding in 2022 by CEO Mikey Shulman—a self-described “former mediocre musician,” MIT lecturer and former head of machine learning at S&P Global subsidiary Kensho. Suno uses artificial intelligence to let users create full songs with lyrics and background music from basic text-based prompts. In June, major record labels including Sony and Warner sued the startup for allegedly copying thousands of their songs to train its AI models. The music generator has surprisingly admitted its software is trained on all the music files openly available on the internet, arguing that doing so is fair use. But the legal snafu hasn't dampened investors' interest. The Cambridge-based startup has scooped up $125 million in funding from investors like Lightspeed Venture Partners and GitHub CEO Nat Friedman and has grown to around 12 million users. Valued at $500 million, per Pitchbook, Suno integrated with Amazon's Alexa earlier this year.

To create videos in 140 languages, simply write a script, pick from one of 230 synthetic avatars and voila! Instavideo. Founded in 2017 by a team of academics and entrepreneurs, Synthesia's generative AI tools are used to create corporate marketing materials as well as influencers' TikTok videos. Big outfits like Reuters and Accenture are among its 65,000 clients. In January, Synthesia landed an additional $180 million in funding and nabbed a $2 billion valuation. CEO Victor Riparbelli—an alumnus of the Forbes 30 Under 30 list—says Synthesia's tech still has room to grow and its avatars could become more realistic. Most recently, Synthesia crossed $100 million in annual recurring revenue and received investment backing from Adobe Ventures for an undisclosed amount.

When OpenAI ousted Sam Altman as CEO two years ago, then-CTO Mira Murati stepped in as interim chief. Her tenure ended four days later, before Altman returned to the company. But now Murati is a CEO again, this time at her own stealthy startup. The firm is coy about what it's working on beyond a focus on science and programming AI. Even minus specifics, the buzz is deafening thanks almost entirely to Murati's reputation: Without revenue, without a product, without a fully defined category, it's said to be planning to raise $1 billion at a valuation of around $9 billion.

San Francisco-based Together AI provides cloud computing services and software to 700,000 AI developers and enterprises like Zoom, Salesforce and Quora to train, fine tune and run AI models. The company is also a staunch advocate for open-source AI technology and hosts 200 open source models for video, image and text generation. Since its founding in 2022, it's become one of the largest resources for open source data to train large language models, thanks to its dataset named RedPajama-V2 that contains more than 30 trillion units of data. Earlier this year, the company reached a valuation of $3.3 billion after closing a $305 million round led by General Catalyst, and acquired Refuel.ai in May.

CEO and cofounder Brett Granberg has described Vannevar Labs as the creator of the tools that will deter the next great conflict. Granberg, who previously worked with the CIA's venture arm, has spent the past six years building the startup into a go-to for national security operations, alongside cofounder Nini Moorhead, a former counterterrorism intelligence officer. Today, Vannevar Labs' artificial intelligence software Decrypt reaches military bases globally, where it is used to analyze documents, translate information and find patterns in battlefield information. The U.S. Air Force, for instance, is using it to analyze technical documents about Russia's anti-aircraft systems. With its most recent $75 million Series B in 2023, Vannevar Labs reached a valuation of $1.5 billion.

VAST Data CEO and founder Renen Hallak made an early, prescient prediction that AI models would face a growing need for data services, so he launched a company in 2016 to provide data management and infrastructure software. Since then, New York City-based VAST Data’s valuation has skyrocketed, nearly tripling from $3.7 billion in 2021 to more than $9 billion in December 2023 after a $118 million series E round. Clients like NASA, Zoom, and Pixar contribute to the $200 million in signed contracts the startup had at the end of 2023.

Windsurf (formerly Codeium) makes software that can auto-generate chunks of code– as much as 100 million lines of it in more than 70 programming languages. The service, part of CEO Varun Mohan's goal of enabling software developers to work faster and more efficiently, offers free and paid subscriptions for individual users and plans starting at $35 per month for teams and companies for the extension. In November, the company launched a new product called “the Windsurf Editor,” which helps a programmer work alongside the AI software, tracking and approving its suggestions. With enterprise traction from the likes of Zillow and Anduril, the startup has nabbed $243 million and a $1.25 billion valuation from investors including Kleiner Perkins, Greenoaks and General Catalyst.

World Labs founder and CEO Fei-Fei Li has AI bona fides in spades: A pioneer in computer vision, the former head of AI for Google Cloud (and AI advisor to California Governor Gavin Newsom) is known in the industry as “the Godmother of AI.” Her latest venture, which she founded while working at Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI, develops AI models that analyze the physical world and generate artificial environments for people to roam and explore as in a video game. It could be useful for things like creating theme park attractions or flight training simulations, and Li has a murderers' row of Silicon Valley investors backing her, including Andreessen Horowitz, Marc Benioff and Reid Hoffman.

Around 300 enterprises, including the likes of Uber, Intuit and Salesforce, use Writer's generative AI software to create marketing materials and other documents in the company's style and voice. Writer's AI models can ingest and process everything from text to spreadsheets and databases and use that information to generate blogs, social media posts and email campaigns. Founded by May Habib and Waseem AlShikh, it has raised a total of $326 million following its most recent Series C in November 2024, which valued the company at $1.9 billion. Now it's releasing 70-plus ready to use AI agents that can autonomously carry out rote tasks across HR, sales, customer support and other areas.

Elon Musk's artificial intelligence company xAI claims its mission is to “understand the true nature of the universe” and “accelerate human scientific discovery.” In late March, the company made a notable acquisition: scooping up X (formerly Twitter) in an all-stock deal that valued the social media platform at $33 billion and the newly merged company at $80 billion. Musk, the world's richest person, owns both entities and said the deal would involve merging their data, models and talent. In June, xAI started building a massive datacenter in Memphis called Colossus that supports a cluster of 100,000 GPUs to train future xAI models. Three months later, part of the supercomputer was online. Not everyone in the city is thrilled about that: Forbes has reported that community members and environment advocates have criticized the speed and secrecy with which the facility was built.
